Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Sustainable scandium supply from industrial wastes enabled by novel chemistry in solid-phase extraction technologies
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will study novel methods for extracting and recovering valuable metals from an abundant industrial waste source, namely coal combustion fly ash. If successful, the technology developed in this project has the potential to reduce the environmental and societal risks of both newly generated- and legacy coal combustion wastes, while strengthening the supply chain security of raw materials critical to advanced technology and green energy applications. Moreover, by establishing a secure long-term supply of affordable scandium, this project can catalyze long-lasting improvements in commercial and personal transportation. Demonstration of this highly-selective, solvent-free metal separations technology may also influence a paradigm shift in the metallurgical industry towards more sustainable practices. Validation of technologies for waste utilization and value creation is an attractive avenue for transitioning coal-dependent regions towards economies based on advanced manufacturing and high-tech jobs.

Previous attempts to extract metals from industrial wastes have suffered from technical limitations that the technology developed in this project overcomes. Based on commercially-available engineered polymer supports, our suite of adsorbents exhibits REE-selective functionality across broad pH regimes, enabling flexible, complementary deployment and high rates of reagent recycle. The goals of this project are to translate the laboratory-scale synthesis schemes for our novel adsorbents to greener, industrially-scalable chemistries and to demonstrate a holistic system prototype that validates the key unit operations of our process together. The former will be accomplished by following well-established protocols of the chemical industry under the supervision of our commercial partner and the latter through extensive, dynamic subsystem testing and finally construction and operation of a lab-scale prototype. The project team expects the final deliverable of this development effort to constitute a high-fidelity demonstration of the process at a Technology Readiness Level of 5.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this Phase I SBIR award was to demonstrate the ability to extract and recover scandium from coal combustion fly ash in a new, environmentally-benign process. Sucess in this objective could have wide ranging benefits by creating an economical source of scandium – which has enormous potential to improve performance of critical materials in the transportation and energy industries – and by remediating one of the most abundant industrial wastes in the US.

In order to accomplish this objective, Anactisis developed adsorbent materials that can very selectively separate scandium from other metals, such as iron and aluminum, and do so in a way that allow for recycling of chemicals within the recovery process. This novel capability was demonstrated using real samples of coal combustion fly ash, proving that fly ash could serve as a resource for producing scandium. Preliminary economic evaluation suggested that the overall process could serve as a commercially viable approach to beneficially reuse these combustion residuals.

As part of this effort, new methods for preparing the adsorbents used for Sc separation were explored. The result of this study was the discovery of water-based methods for adsorbent production that dramatically improved production cost, ease of production, and environmental and worker safety. These new methods will expedite the scale-up of adsorbent production necessary for the next stages of process development.

In demonstrating the technical feasibility of recovering scandium from an industrial waste, this project has garnered considerable interest from the coal-power industry as well as potential downstream users of scandium. Technical and commercial factors limit the reuse of coal fly ash to 50-60% of annual production. New capabilities, such as those demonstrated in this project, could potentially increase reuse to 100%. In doing so, this process would create new, transformative opportunities for scandium use that were previously constrained by a lack of reliable supply.
